section.title: Definitional Operators
section.para:
is one of the few description logics for which standard reasoning problems such as consistency, and concept subsumption are decidable in polynomial time. To gain this tractability, commonly-used constructors such as universal value restrictions, inverse roles, and functional roles have been sacrificed.
Comparison of Reasoners for large Ontologies in the OWL 2 EL Profile. Kathrin Dentler, Ronald Cornet, Annette ten Teije, and Nicolette de Keizer

section.title: Role inclusions
section.para: role inclusions allow expression of role hierarchies, transitive roles and right identities.

section.title: Defining relationships
section.para: Role relationship are represented as existential restrictions

section.title: Quantities
section.para:
Concrete domains are a construct that can define new classes by specifying restrictions on attributes that have literal values (as opposed to relationships to other concepts). The binary operators, equal to, greater than, greater than or equal to, less than, and less than or equal to, can be used in concrete domain expressions, and literal values can be integers, floating point numbers, string literals, and dates.
SNOROCKET 2.0 Concurrent Domains and Concurrent Classification
Concrete domains are used to model quantities in the definition of concepts, such as defining how much ibuprofen may be in a medication tablet.

section.title: "Not Elsewhere Classified" Revisited
section.para: Each concept used as a [interpretation, qualifier, ?], within a value set, must be accompanied by sufficient information to reconstruct the value set, and the value set must provide a partial order such that the concept's "range" of meaning can be determined.

For example, a concept representing a color selected from the value set {Red, Green, Blue} will have a different range than a color selected from the value set {Red, Orange, Green, Yellow, Blue (get a better example of a granular color set ordered properly by em spectrum)}.
Create a set of "intrepretative concepts," or a similar construct, that is the intrepretation of that concept when constrainted by a value set...
Same preferred name, fully specified name incorporates the identify of the refset that constrained the concept.

section.title: Values from Constraints
section.para: If a concept is used as an intrepretation, the values from which they were selected must accompany somehow so that the value can be determined against a partial ordering.
Interpretation concepts can have children just like the can have units of measure?
